items.title: Will Trump Meet Kim Jong-un Again? He’s Very Open to the Idea.
items.summary: President Trump has said he hopes the North Korean leader will reach out so they can meet again. But there has been no public response from Mr. Kim.

items.title: Amid a Record Party Investment, Two Candidates for Governor Join Forces
items.summary: Representative Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey and former Representative Abigail Spanberger of Virginia will appear together on Wednesday, hoping to energize Democratic campaign volunteers, and voters.

items.title: What to Know About Tear Gas, the Chemicals Federal Agents Are Using During Immigration Raids
items.summary: The repeated use of tear gas by federal immigration officers in Chicago has renewed a debate about how chemical irritants should be used by law enforcement personnel.

items.title: Judge Expected to Quiz Gregory Bovino Over Immigration Crackdown Tactics
items.summary: Gregory Bovino, a border patrol official who has become a public face of President Trump’s crackdown, was ordered to appear in a Chicago courtroom.

items.title: A City Council Race in Arizona Turns Toxic Over Charlie Kirk’s Legacy
items.summary: By nationalizing a local election, Turning Point Action is trying to show it can carry on without its founder and recall a local Republican who endorsed Kamala Harris.

items.title: A Twist in the Candy Cane Park Murder Investigation in Oregon
items.summary: An unlikely twist in the investigation of a killing in 1983 that still haunts a small town in Oregon.

items.title: Trump and new Japanese prime minister share praise and vow to strengthen ‘remarkable’ relationship – US politics live
items.summary: <p>The president also suggested he could deploy the National Guard in more US cities at an address aboard the US naval base</p><p>In a <a href="https://democrats-judiciary.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/democrats-judiciary.house.gov/files/evo-media-document/2025-10-27-raskin-et-al-to-bondi-blanche-woodward-doj-re-trump-230m-payout_0.pdf">new letter</a>, House Democrats are warning three top Justice Department officials—including two who previously defended Donald Trump in criminal proceedings—that they could face prosecution if they approve Donald Trump’s suggestion of a $230 million payment from American taxpayers.</p><p>They are calling it “perhaps the most brazen violation” of constitutional anti-corruption provisions in US history.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2025/oct/28/donald-trump-sanae-takaichi-japan-trade-national-guard-us-politics-live">Continue reading...</a>

items.title: Haitians helped boost Springfield’s economy – now they’re fleeing in fear of Trump
items.summary: <p>Ohio city’s economic fortunes spiral and local businesses suffer as Haitians leave due to administration’s anti-immigrant rhetoric and policies</p><p>Every morning, Alicia Mercado makes the 50-minute drive from her home in Columbus to Springfield, where she runs the Adasa Latin Market store. She opened the business next to a Haitian restaurant in 2023, having spotted a gap in the market for Caribbean and Latin foods – the neighborhood’s Haitian population was booming at the time.</p><p>But over the past year, she says her business, which includes an international money transfer kiosk, has taken a major hit.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/28/springfield-ohio-economy-haitians-trump-immigration">Continue reading...</a>
